tables.name: Plans
tables.description: Strategic-level view of all major projects in the Robkei ecosystem. Each project represents a significant initiative with defined timeline, budget, objectives, and success criteria. Projects contain phases which break down the work into manageable chunks.

fields.name: plan_id
fields.description: Unique plan identifier using hierarchical format. Format: P## (e.g., P01, P02). Sequential numbering for each plan. Example: P01

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: owner
fields.description: Person or team responsible for overall delivery. Use consistent naming: Team name or individual email/ID Example: ML Team

fields.name: duration
fields.description: Estimated duration. Format: #w (weeks) or #d (days)

fields.name: budget
fields.description: Budget allocation in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: parent_plan
fields.description: ID of parent plan for hierarchical planning. Format: ##

fields.name: depends_on_plans
fields.description: Plans this Plan depends on (must complete before this Plan starts)

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

tables.name: Phases
tables.description: Tactical-level breakdown of projects into major phases. Each phase has specific objectives, deliverables, and timeline. Phases contain stages (sub-phases) and roll up progress from those stages. Dependencies between phases can be tracked.

fields.name: phase_id
fields.description: Unique phase identifier with plan reference. Format: P##.## (e.g., P01.01). First part is plan, second is phase number. Example: P01.03

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: duration
fields.description: Estimated duration. Format: #w (weeks) or #d (days)

fields.name: owner
fields.description: Person or team responsible for overall delivery. Use consistent naming: Team name or individual email/ID Example: ML Team

fields.name: estimated_budget
fields.description: Estimated budget in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: predecessor
fields.description: Predecessor phase ID (##.##)

prompt:
You are an AI tasked with evaluating the strategic planning quality of a phase record. Your expertise lies in assessing project documentation for completeness and clarity.

Begin by calculating a base score of 30 points. Evaluate critical requirements by checking the length of the notes, presence of dollar amounts, hour estimates, countable deliverables, and success metrics. Detect generic content and apply penalties for phrases like "Complete phase" or "Execute stages". Score each field based on specific criteria, such as format validation and content specificity.

Output the score as a plain text string starting with "Score: [number]". Follow with planning quality, budget, timeline, deliverables, and success metrics findings. If the score is below 60, provide a remediation message. Do not include any additional text or formatting.

Context and Data:
Phase ID:

fields.name: record_audit
fields.description: Evaluates the strategic planning quality of a phase based on specific criteria and outputs a score with detailed analysis.

fields.name: record_score
fields.description: Extracts the assigned score from the record_audit field, defaulting to 0 if no score is present.

fields.name: plan_link
fields.description: Link to parent plan record

tables.name: Stages
tables.description: Operational-level sub-phases within each phase (e.g., Phase 1a, 1b, 1c). Each stage represents a cohesive unit of work with clear charge (directive) and outcome (deliverables). Stages contain individual tasks and define autonomy levels.

fields.name: stage_id
fields.description: Unique stage identifier with phase reference. Format: S##.## (e.g., S02.15). Maps to specific work stream. Example: S02.30

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: plan_link
fields.description: Link to parent plan record

fields.name: blocked_by
fields.description: ID of blocking stage/task

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

prompt:
You are an evaluator assessing the quality of tactical planning for a stage in a project. Your expertise lies in identifying key deliverables, technical approaches, dependencies, and task quantification.

Begin by calculating a base score of 35 points. Evaluate the notes for length, named outputs, technical methods, dependencies, and task count. Apply penalties for generic content and missing critical requirements. Score each field based on specific criteria, adding points for valid formats and specific objectives.

Output the score as a plain text string starting with "Score: [number]". Follow with a quality assessment, named outputs count, technical method presence, dependencies presence, and task count. If the score is below 60, provide a remediation message detailing missing specifications. Do not include any additional text.

Context and Data:
Stage ID:

fields.name: record_audit
fields.description: Evaluates the completeness and uniqueness of content within a record, assigning a score based on quality.

fields.name: record_score
fields.description: Extracts the agent assigned score from the record audit text data.

tables.name: Tasks
tables.description: Execution-level individual actionable tasks with complete metadata. Each task has detailed charge (instructions), outcome (success criteria), cost tracking, resource requirements, dependencies, and knowledge capture. This is where work actually gets done.

fields.name: task_id
fields.description: Unique task identifier with full hierarchy. Format: T##.##.## (e.g., T02.30.01). Shows phase.stage.task structure. Example: T02.30.05

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: priority
fields.description: Relative importance and urgency of the item. Select from: Critical | High | Medium | Low. Consider dependencies and deadlines. Example: High

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: assigned_to
fields.description: Individual currently working on this task. Use email or employee ID for consistency Example: john.smith@company.com

fields.name: estimated_hours
fields.description: Estimated effort in hours to complete. Use realistic estimates. Include testing and documentation time. Example: 8

fields.name: actual_hours
fields.description: Actual hours spent (for tracking and improvement). Track actual time for better future estimates Example: 10.5

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: artifacts
fields.description: Deliverables and outputs produced. List files, models, or documentation created Example: bigquery_schema.sql, data_pipeline.py, architecture.md

fields.name: plan_link
fields.description: Link to parent plan record

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: blockers
fields.description: Current impediments preventing progress. Clearly describe what is blocking and what is needed to unblock Example: Waiting for GCP quota increase approval (ticket #12345)

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

prompt:
# Rationalized TASKS Prompt - Implementation Code Quality

## Evaluate the quality of the implementation in this Tasks record.

### Task Description
You are an AI tasked with assessing the implementation quality of a task record. Your role is to evaluate the task based on executable code, specific values, BQX windows, and complete formulas. Use a professional and analytical tone.

### Step-by-Step Process
1. **Calculate Base Score**: Start with 40 points.
2. **Check Critical Requirements**: Evaluate the length of

. Apply a penalty of -60 points if less than 500 characters. Check for code blocks with 5+ lines and specific values like R²=0.35. Ensure references to BQX windows [45,90,180,360,720,1440,2880].
3. **Detect Generic Content**: Identify phrases like "Complete implementation" and apply a penalty of -50 points for each occurrence.
4. **Count Valid Code Blocks**: Ensure code blocks have proper syntax and are not just imports or comments. Check for BQX-specific implementation.
5. **Score Each Field**: Add points based on the format and content of

.
6. **Apply Major Penalties**: Deduct points for missing code blocks, specific values, or BQX context.
7. **Calculate Final Score**: Total = Base (40) + Field Points - Penalties. Ensure the score is between 1 and 100.
8. **Generate Output**: Provide a score, code quality assessment, count of valid code blocks, and presence of specific values and BQX windows.

### Output Format
- Output the score as "Score: [Total]".
- Provide a code quality assessment as "Code Quality: [None/Poor/Fair/Good/Excellent]".
- Include the count of valid code blocks as "Code Blocks: [Count]".
- Indicate the presence of specific values and BQX windows as "Specific Values: [Yes/No]" and "BQX Windows: [Yes/No]".
- If the score is below 70, output a remediation message: "INSUFFICIENT CONTENT. Required: Add actual Python/SQL code, include specific calculations with BQX windows, provide numerical thresholds, expand notes, and reference code examples."

### Context and Data
Task ID:

fields.name: record_audit
fields.description: Evaluates the implementation quality of a task record based on code and specific criteria.

fields.name: record_score
fields.description: Extracts the agent assigned score from the 'record_audit' cell content.

fields.name: reconciled
fields.description: Indicates whether the task_id, plan_link, phase_link, and stage_link are reconciled.
